refnamediv.refpurpose: Functions to run the rendering pipeline

refsynopsisdiv.title: Synopsis

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The Pango rendering pipeline takes a string of Unicode characters and converts it into glyphs. The functions described in this section accomplish various steps of this process.

refsect2.title: struct PangoContext
refsect2.para: The PangoContext structure stores global information used to control the itemization process.

refsect2.title: struct PangoItem
refsect2.para: The PangoItem structure stores information about a segment of text. It contains the following fields:

listitem.simpara: the offset of the segment from the beginning of the string in bytes.
the length of the segment in bytes.
the length of the segment in characters.

refsect2.title: struct PangoAnalysis
refsect2.para: The PangoAnalysis structure stores information about the properties of a segment of text. It has the following fields:

listitem.simpara: the engine for doing rendering-system-dependent processing.
the engine for doing rendering-system-independent processing.
the bidrectional level for this segment.

refsect2.title: enum PangoDirection
refsect2.para: The PangoDirection type represents a direction in the Unicode bidirectional algorithm; not every value in this enumeration makes sense for every usage of PangoDirection; for example, the return value of pango_unichar_direction() and pango_find_base_direction() cannot be PANGO_DIRECTION_WEAK_LTR or PANGO_DIRECTION_WEAK_RTL, since every character is either neutral or has a strong direction; on the other hand PANGO_DIRECTION_NEUTRAL doesn't make sense to pass to pango_log2vis_get_embedding_levels().

The PANGO_DIRECTION_TTB_LTR, PANGO_DIRECTION_TTB_RTL values come from an earlier interpretation of this enumeration as the writing direction of a block of text and are no longer used; See the Text module of the CSS3 spec for how vertical text is planned to be handled in a future version of Pango. The explanation of why PANGO_DIRECTION_TTB_LTR is treated as PANGO_DIRECTION_RTL can be found there as well.

listitem.simpara: Deprecated value; treated the same as PANGO_DIRECTION_RTL.
Deprecated value; treated the same as PANGO_DIRECTION_LTR

refsect2.title: PANGO_TYPE_DIRECTION
refsect2.para: The GObject type for PangoDirection.

refsect2.title: pango_itemize ()
refsect2.programlisting: GList* pango_itemize (PangoContext *context, const char *text, int start_index, int length, PangoAttrList *attrs, PangoAttrIterator *cached_iter);
refsect2.para: Breaks a piece of text into segments with consistent directional level and shaping engine. Each byte of text will be contained in exactly one of the items in the returned list; the generated list of items will be in logical order (the start offsets of the items are ascending).

cached_iter should be an iterator over attrs currently positioned at a range before or containing start_index; cached_iter will be advanced to the range covering the position just after start_index + length. (i.e. if itemizing in a loop, just keep passing in the same cached_iter).

listitem.simpara: a structure holding information that affects the itemization process.
first byte in text to process
the number of bytes (not characters) to process after start_index. This must be >= 0.
the set of attributes that apply to text.

refsect2.title: pango_itemize_with_base_dir ()
refsect2.programlisting: GList* pango_itemize_with_base_dir (PangoContext *context, PangoDirection base_dir, const char *text, int start_index, int length, PangoAttrList *attrs, PangoAttrIterator *cached_iter);
refsect2.para: Like pango_itemize(), but the base direction to use when computing bidirectional levels (see pango_context_set_base_dir()), is specified explicitely rather than gotten from the PangoContext.

listitem.simpara: a structure holding information that affects the itemization process.
base direction to use for bidirectional processing
first byte in text to process
the number of bytes (not characters) to process after start_index. This must be >= 0.
the set of attributes that apply to text.

refsect2.title: pango_item_free ()
refsect2.para: Free a PangoItem and all associated memory.

refsect2.title: pango_item_copy ()
refsect2.para: Copy an existing PangoItem structure.

refsect2.title: pango_item_new ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new PangoItem structure initialized to default values.

refsect2.title: pango_item_split ()
refsect2.para: Modifies orig to cover only the text after split_index, and returns a new item that covers the text before split_index that used to be in orig. You can think of split_index as the length of the returned item. split_index may not be 0, and it may not be greater than or equal to the length of orig (that is, there must be at least one byte assigned to each item, you can't create a zero-length item). split_offset is the length of the first item in chars, and must be provided because the text used to generate the item isn't available, so pango_item_split() can't count the char length of the split items itself.

listitem.simpara: byte index of position to split item, relative to the start of the item
number of chars between start of orig and split_index
new item representing text before split_index

refsect2.title: pango_reorder_items ()
refsect2.para: From a list of items in logical order and the associated directional levels, produce a list in visual order. The original list is unmodified.

listitem.simpara: a GList of PangoItem in logical order.

a GList of PangoItem structures in visual order.
(Please mail otaylorredhat.com if you use this function. It is not a particularly convenient interface, and the code is duplicated elsewhere in Pango for that reason.)

refsect2.title: pango_context_new ()
refsect2.para: Creates a new PangoContext initialized to default value.

This function is only useful when implementing a new backend for Pango, something applications won't do. You should use the context creation function for the backend you are using, for example, pango_xft_get_context(), pango_win32_get_context() or, pango_ft2_font_map_create_context().

If you are using Pango as part of a higher-level system, that system may have it's own ways of create a PangoContext. For instance, the GTK+ toolkit has, among others, gdk_pango_context_get_for_screen(), and gtk_widget_get_pango_context().

refsect2.title: pango_context_set_font_map ()
refsect2.para: Sets the font map to be searched when fonts are looked-up in this context. This is only for internal use by Pango backends, a PangoContext obtained via one of the recommended methods should already have a suitable font map.

refsect2.title: pango_context_get_font_description ()
refsect2.para: Retrieve the default font description for the context.

listitem.simpara: a pointer to the context's default font description. This value must not be modified or freed.

refsect2.title: pango_context_set_font_description ()
refsect2.para: Set the default font description for the context

refsect2.title: pango_context_get_language ()
refsect2.para: Retrieves the global language tag for the context.

refsect2.title: pango_context_set_language ()
refsect2.para: Sets the global language tag for the context.

refsect2.title: pango_context_get_base_dir ()
refsect2.para: Retrieves the base direction for the context. See pango_context_set_base_dir().

listitem.simpara: the base direction for the context.

refsect2.title: pango_context_set_base_dir ()
refsect2.para: Sets the base direction for the context.

The base direction is used in applying the Unicode bidirectional algorithm; if the direction is PANGO_DIRECTION_LTR or PANGO_DIRECTION_RTL, then the value will be used as the paragraph direction in the Unicode bidirectional algorithm. A value of PANGO_DIRECTION_WEAK_LTR or PANGO_DIRECTION_WEAK_RTL is used only for paragraphs that do not contain any strong characters themselves.

refsect2.title: pango_context_load_font ()
refsect2.para: Loads the font in one of the fontmaps in the context that is the closest match for desc.

listitem.simpara: a PangoFontDescription describing the font to load
the font loaded, or NULL if no font matched.

refsect2.title: pango_context_load_fontset ()
refsect2.para: Load a set of fonts in the context that can be used to render a font matching desc.

listitem.simpara: a PangoFontDescription describing the fonts to load
a PangoLanguage the fonts will be used for
the fontset, or NULL if no font matched.

refsect2.title: pango_context_get_metrics ()
refsect2.para: Get overall metric information for a font particular font description. Since the metrics may be substantially different for different scripts, a language tag can be provided to indicate that the metrics should be retrieved that correspond to the script(s) used by that language.

The PangoFontDescription is interpreted in the same way as by pango_itemize(), and the family name may be a comma separated list of figures. If characters from multiple of these families would be used to render the string, then the returned fonts would be a composite of the metrics for the fonts loaded for the individual families.

listitem.simpara: language tag used to determine which script to get the metrics for, or NULL to indicate to get the metrics for the entire font.
a PangoMetrics object. The caller must call pango_font_metrics_unref() when finished using the object.

refsect2.title: pango_context_list_families ()
refsect2.para: List all families for a context.

listitem.simpara: location to store a pointer to an array of PangoFontFamily *. This array should be freed with g_free().
location to store the number of elements in descs

refsect2.title: pango_unichar_direction ()
refsect2.para: Determines the direction of a character; either PANGO_DIRECTION_LTR, PANGO_DIRECTION_LTR, or PANGO_DIRECTION_NEUTRAL.

listitem.simpara: the direction of a character, as used in the Unicode bidirectional algorithm.

refsect2.title: pango_find_base_dir ()
refsect2.para: Searches a string the first character that has a strong direction, according to the Unicode bidirectional algorithm.

listitem.simpara: length of text in bytes (may be -1 if text is nul-terminated)
The direction corresponding to the first strong character. If no such character is found, then PANGO_DIRECTION_NEUTRAL is returned.

refsect2.title: pango_break ()
refsect2.programlisting: void pango_break (const gchar *text, int length, PangoAnalysis *analysis, PangoLogAttr *attrs, int attrs_len);
refsect2.para: Determines possible line, word, and character breaks for a string of Unicode text.

listitem.simpara: length of text in bytes (may be -1 if text is nul-terminated)
an array to store character information in
size of the array passed as attrs

refsect2.title: pango_get_log_attrs ()
refsect2.programlisting: void pango_get_log_attrs (const char *text, int length, int level, PangoLanguage *language, PangoLogAttr *log_attrs, int attrs_len);
refsect2.para: Computes a PangoLogAttr for each character in text. The log_attrs array must have one PangoLogAttr for each position in text; if text contains N characters, it has N+1 positions, including the last position at the end of the text. text should be an entire paragraph; logical attributes can't be computed without context (for example you need to see spaces on either side of a word to know the word is a word).

listitem.simpara: array with one PangoLogAttr per character in text, plus one extra, to be filled in

refsect2.title: pango_find_paragraph_boundary ()
refsect2.programlisting: void pango_find_paragraph_boundary (const gchar *text, gint length, gint *paragraph_delimiter_index, gint *next_paragraph_start);
refsect2.para: Locates a paragraph boundary in text. A boundary is caused by delimiter characters, such as a newline, carriage return, carriage return-newline pair, or Unicode paragraph separator character. The index of the run of delimiters is returned in paragraph_delimiter_index. The index of the start of the paragraph (index after all delimiters) is stored in next_paragraph_start.
If no delimiters are found, both paragraph_delimiter_index and next_paragraph_start are filled with the length of text (an index one off the end).

listitem.simpara: length of text in bytes, or -1 if nul-terminated
return location for index of delimiter
return location for start of next paragraph

refsect2.title: pango_default_break ()
refsect2.programlisting: void pango_default_break (const gchar *text, int length, PangoAnalysis *analysis, PangoLogAttr *attrs, int attrs_len);
refsect2.para: This is the default break algorithm, used if no language engine overrides it. Normally you should use pango_break() instead; this function is mostly useful for chaining up from a language engine override. Unlike pango_break(), analysis can be NULL, but only do that if you know what you're doing. (If you need an analysis to pass to pango_break(), you need to pango_itemize() or use pango_get_log_attrs().)

listitem.simpara: length of text in bytes (may be -1 if text is nul-terminated)
size of the array passed as attrs

refsect2.title: struct PangoLogAttr
refsect2.para: The PangoLogAttr structure stores information about the attributes of a single character.

listitem.simpara: If set, backspace deletes one character rather than the entire grapheme cluster. This field is only meaningful on grapheme boundaries (where is_cursor_position is set). In some languages, the full grapheme (e.g. letter + diacritics) is considered a unit, while in others, each decomposed character in the grapheme is a unit. In the default implementation of pango_break, this bit is set on all grapheme boundaries except those following Latin, Cyrillic or Greek base characters.

refsect2.title: pango_shape ()
refsect2.programlisting: void pango_shape (const gchar *text, gint length, PangoAnalysis *analysis, PangoGlyphString *glyphs);
refsect2.para: Given a segment of text and the corresponding PangoAnalysis structure returned from pango_itemize(), convert the characters into glyphs. You may also pass in only a substring of the item from pango_itemize().

listitem.simpara: glyph string in which to store results
